question: What is the most common element in the Sun?

content.source_1: Observations and standard solar models agree that Sun-like main-sequence stars are composed primarily of hydrogen, with helium second; in the Sun, hydrogen accounts for roughly three-quarters of the mass (and the large majority of atoms).
content.source_2: Spectroscopy and helioseismology jointly support that hydrogen remains the dominant element in the bulk of a G-type main-sequence star such as the Sun during its main-sequence lifetime.
content.source_3: In Sun-like stars, hydrogen fusion in the core steadily converts hydrogen into helium, so the core becomes increasingly helium-rich as the star ages; in the present Sun’s core, helium exceeds hydrogen.
content.source_4: The overwhelming majority of a star’s mass lies in its deep interior (core and radiative zone); the outer atmosphere contributes a negligible fraction of the total mass.
content.source_5: In solar-type stars, heavier species such as helium undergo gravitational settling in radiative regions, diffusing downward and becoming relatively enhanced beneath the convection zone over time.
content.source_6: The Sun is about 4.6 billion years old—roughly midway through its ~10-billion-year main-sequence life—so a substantial amount of helium “ash” has accumulated in its interior.
